image.altText: An ambulance driving past the Royal Adelaide Hospital

props.synopsis: Ambulance ramping hours in South Australia rose to their third-highest level on record in May, with the latest surge prompting concerns about a long winter ahead.

title.children: SA ambulance ramping rising again, prompting 'grave concerns' for winter

image.altText: lady sitting on orange couch smiling at camera

props.synopsis: When Geranium Primary School was forced to close its doors due to dwindling enrolment numbers, it shut a century-old chapter for the tiny town. But then one former teacher with big dreams stepped in to help her town blossom again.

title.children: Town of 80 buys old primary school for $1.10 and turns it into op shop

image.altText: Cam Rayner and Jaspa Fletcher walk off Adelaide Oval together.

props.synopsis: A frantic finish in Adelaide as the Crows, sparked by Josh Rachele and Ben Keays, hold on to beat the Brisbane Lions for their best win of the season at Adelaide Oval.

title.children: 'A game we should have won': Lions give blunt assessment of loss to Crows

image.altText: Aerial view of trees and water in Lake Eyre.

props.synopsis: Lake Eyre being full is not just a once-in-a-lifetime moment it's also a chance for outback towns to feast on tourism.

title.children: Lake Eyre comes alive as floodwaters help with once in a generation fill

image.altText: The interior of a large industrial plant

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has set aside another $384 million to keep the Whyalla steelworks running next financial year — doubling the amount already allocated to keep the plant operating during administration.

title.children: $384m contingency to keep Whyalla steelworks afloat

image.altText: Stephen Mullighan holds the 2025 SA state budget papers as he stands oustide with tall city buildings behind him

props.synopsis: Despite saying South Australia doesn't have a law and order problem, the Malinauskas government has delivered a budget which spruiks funding for law and order, including a $172 million spend to increase the state's police force.

title.children: The curious case of South Australia's law and order budget

image.altText: The Milky Way shines brightly above a country town during a blackout.

props.synopsis: Electricity companies that breach their licenses should be forced to compensate customers, an inquiry into a prolonged blackout in Far West New South Wales has found.

title.children: Power companies should pay compensation for blackouts, report finds

image.altText: Image of man with serious face and black shirt

props.synopsis: A man who "savagely" attacked and stabbed former Bachelorette contestant Paddy Colliar, who was working as a topless waiter at a 60th birthday party, has been jailed for at least four years.

title.children: Man jailed for four years over stabbing of 'good Samaritan' former reality TV contestant

image.altText: A full street with people marching with flags and signs . one says liberation freedom restitution.

props.synopsis: Mr White died last Tuesday after he was restrained by off-duty officers on the floor of a Coles supermarket in Alice Springs.

title.children: 'We ask for justice': Hundreds rally in Brisbane over death of Kumanjayi White

image.altText: Forestry in SA's south-east

props.synopsis: As Australia looks to meet housing construction targets, companies in SA and Victoria's Green Triangle are investing more heavily in softwood timber.

title.children: Housing demand drives forestry companies' shift from blue gum to pine

image.altText: A protest sign sits next to a council sign.

props.synopsis: Port Lincoln residents push back against a proposal from their council to develop five parcels of land for housing.

title.children: Residents say council push to develop green space 'concerning'

image.altText: John Griffin

props.synopsis: John Edward Tilly Griffin has been jailed for more than nine years for the manslaughter of Gary Robinson at Port Neill in September 2023, in which Mr Robinson was left covered in shampoo, sprinkles and birdseed.

title.children: Killer inflicted 'blows of considerable force' before throwing sprinkles on victim

image.altText: Pigs in a pen.

props.synopsis: About 270 people will lose their jobs and multiple communities will be impacted with the pending closure of a rural South Australian pork processing plant.

title.children: Pork abattoir closure rubs 'salt in injury' for drought-hit towns

image.altText: A purple sign reads Vinarchy, Redefining Wine. It is surrounded by two yellow tanks.

props.synopsis: A global wine giant will close two well-known cellar doors in South Australia's key wine regions, creating uncertainty for staff.

title.children: Wine giant's shock closure of Banrock Station end of a 'fantastic marriage'

image.altText: A man in a high-visibility shirt with his arm around his teenage son, who is also wearing a high-visibility shirt

props.synopsis: Businesses are feeling flow-on impacts and cutting jobs after Whyalla's steelworks went into administration.

title.children: Job losses flow down the line from troubled SA steelworks

image.altText: A stock pot of homemade chicken and vegetable soup with a ladle. Three bowls of soup sit alongside with a girl eating one

props.synopsis: A flavour-packed chicken soup with slow-cooked onions, chunky root vegetables and peas. It's simple cooking and wholly nourishing.

title.children: Make this simple and nourishing chicken and vegetable soup your go-to

image.altText: A young Thai man looks towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Pinta Nattapong, 35, was working in Israel as a farm worker when he was kidnapped from Kibbutz Nir Oz and killed in captivity shortly afterwards, according to the Israeli government.

title.children: Israel retrieves body of Thai hostage kidnapped during October 7 attacks

image.altText: GWS captain Toby Greene holds his hip in discomfort as he limps on the ground with a trainer during a game.

props.synopsis: GWS fall short in Canberra without injured skipper Toby Greene, putting their top-eight spot in jeopardy as the Power grab vital win on the road for coach Ken Hinkley. Follow live.

title.children: Giants fall short in Canberra without Greene as Power win one for Hinkley

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Toby Greene is subbed out for GWS

image.altText: A photo of an Aldi sign

props.synopsis: It's no secret that Aldi sells products visually similar to those of its well-established competitors. But using Australian courts to force the retailer to change its ways is no easy task.

title.children: How Aldi sails 'close to the wind' on branding and packaging

image.altText: A close up of Harvey Weinstein.

props.synopsis: Jurors are deliberating after hearing six weeks of evidence in the New York retrial of Harvey Weinstein. Here's how it unfolded.

title.children: What happened at Harvey Weinstein's New York rape and sexual assault retrial

image.altText: Simone Biles smiling, holding the gold medal around her neck, on the Olympic podium

props.synopsis: Olympic gymnast Simone Biles has called former US college swimmer Riley Gaines "sick" for mocking a social media post about a high school softball team with a trans player.

title.children: 'Straight up sore loser': Biles calls out former swimmer for trans stance

image.altText: Two male politicians sitting in a chamber of parliament.

props.synopsis: If the past few days in Tasmanian politics were a horror movie, this weekend is a thriller — filled with suspense and the knowledge that something unknown is just around the corner.

title.children: After a wild few days, Tasmanian voters are now being held in suspense

image.altText: A satellite image shows three destroyed aircraft sitting on a tarmac that runs between verdants strips of grass and trees.

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin's online army is normally supportive, but some accounts have been boldly outspoken and willing to question, even blame, the Russian establishment for not protecting the country's prized strategic bomber fleet.

title.children: As Russian planes burned, Putin's military bloggers were 'choking with hurt'

image.altText: Jai Opetaia walking onto a stage, wearing boxing gloves, for a public training session

props.synopsis: The two-way respect earned in an evening with Terence Crawford could pay off in the form of a Las Vegas stadium unification blockbuster for the 29-year-old Australian.

title.children: Jai Opetaia hunting another win to earn potential Las Vegas pay-off

image.altText: An old building with blue mesh fencing around it and trees

props.synopsis: Derelict Queensland island resorts that were once playgrounds for the rich and famous are facing a state government takeover, amid frustrations they have been used for land banking.

title.children: Paradise lost: Queensland's derelict island resorts face government takeover

image.altText: A police image of a blue Subaru Liberty believed to have been involved in the collision.

props.synopsis: Police are seeking assistance after a Chinese national on holiday in Melbourne was struck in an alleged hit-run and left with two broken legs.

title.children: Police appeal for help after alleged hit-run that broke pedestrian's legs

image.altText: A couple hold up peace signs to the camera.

props.synopsis: Across China, a growing number of young heterosexual women are fed up with traditional pressures around marriage and sexism and choosing to stay single.

title.children: China's falling birth rate meets a #boysober dating revolution

image.altText: A young woman, smiling, and kicking up snow.

props.synopsis: Alpine resorts could not be happier with up to 19 centimetres of fresh snow recorded overnight — and more snow to come.

title.children: Fresh snow marks the official opening of the Victorian ski season

image.altText: North Korean destroyer AP News

props.synopsis: North Korea has raised a capsized warship and moored it at a pier in the north-eastern port of Chongjin, as it continues to repair the new vessel. Leader Kim Jong Un has described it as a significant asset for his nuclear-armed military.

title.children: North Korea rights capsized warship after failed launch

image.altText: Donald Trump reuters

props.synopsis: It's a rocky road for global financial markets and most are treading very carefully.

title.children: Australians could enjoy an upside from US economic policy uncertainty

image.altText: Priya sign

props.synopsis: The federal government has promised to close the loophole that allowed employers to cancel paid parental leave after a stillbirth or early infant death.

title.children: Law to change after mother's paid parental leave cancelled when baby died

image.altText: A sketch of Erin Patterson wearing a blue jumper and thin framed black glasses with her hair tied back.

props.synopsis: The 50-year-old, who has pleaded not guilty to three charges of murder and one of attempted murder, admitted several times she had used lies and exaggeration in the past.

title.children: Erin Patterson's week on the stand in her mushroom murder trial

image.altText: School building with red open sign out the front of it

props.synopsis: When Geranium Primary School was forced to close its doors due to dwindling enrolment numbers, it shut a century-old chapter for the tiny town. But then one former teacher with big dreams stepped in to her help her town blossom again.

title.children: Town of 80 buys old primary school for $1.10 and turns it into op shop

image.altText: Donald Trump holding tariff sign with beef

props.synopsis: The beef trade between Australia and the United States is currently a one-way street. That's unlikely to change.

title.children: Demand for Aussie beef outweighs Trump tariffs

image.altText: A woman with dark hair embraces a man in a suit with a solemn expression outside a red brick building.

props.synopsis: The atmosphere in the Devonport Magistrates Court was tense as Magistrate Robert Webster announced Rosemary Gamble was not guilty in the only criminal case to come from the Hillcrest Primary School jumping castle tragedy.

title.children: 'Broken' families tell of anger and disappointment following Hillcrest verdict
